required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Sintilimab Combined With Chemotherapy and SBRT in Limited Metastatic Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma (LM-HNSCC)
clinical_study.official_title: Phase II Clinical Study of Sintilimab Combined With Platinum-based Chemotherapy and SBRT in the First-line Treatment of Limited Metastatic Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma

brief_summary.textblock: To evaluate the safety and efficacy of combination of Sintilimab and SBRT on the basis of platinum-containing chemotherapy as the first-line treatment of limited metastatic head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (LM-HNSCC).

detailed_description.textblock: For patients with LM-HNSCC, the conventional first-line treatment is EXTREME regimen dominated systemic therapy. In the recent era, immunotherapy has emerged to be the paramount issue for cancer treatment. A series of high-quality clinical studies demonstrated that immunotherapy (such as PD1 inhibitor) with or without chemotherapy (depending on CPS status) offered significant survival benefits to patients with recurrent or metastatic (R/M) HNSCC and the toxicities were well tolerated, whereas the PFS was still dismal. SBRT is associated with initiating release of tumor antigens, promoting DC activation, activating APCs, priming CD8+ CTLs, leading to the potential of abscopal effect. Therefore, we hypothesized that adding SBRT to Sintilimab (a PD1 inhibitor) and platinum-containing chemotherapy as the first-line treatment may improve the PFS for limited metastatic head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (LM-HNSCC).

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Prospective, single center, single arm, phase II clinical study

primary_outcome.description: PFS is defined as the duration from the starting date of per-protocol treatment to first progression of disease, death or closure of study.

secondary_outcome.description: OS was calculated from the starting date of per-protocol treatment to death from any cause.
CR + PR rate according to the RECIST version 1.1 guidelines.
CR + PR + SD rate according to the RECIST version 1.1 guidelines.
The time from the date of first identification of response (CR or PR) to progression/death (P/D).

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to progression of initial lesions (TPIL)
secondary_outcome.description: The time from the first date of per-protocol treatment to progression of baseline lesions or death.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to progression of new lesions (TPNL)
secondary_outcome.description: The time from the first date of per-protocol treatment to the appearance of new lesion of tumor or death.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to progression of non-irradiated lesions (TPNRL)
secondary_outcome.description: Duration from the first date of per-protocol treatment to the specific progression of non-irradiated lesion or death.
Adverse event assessment according to NCI CTCAE 5.0, including AE, TEAE, SAE and irAE.

clinical_study.condition: Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma

arm_group.description: Sintilimab combined with platinum-based chemotherapy and SBRT

intervention.description: Sintilimab: 200mg, administered by intravenous infusion on the first day of each cycle, one cycle every 3 weeks (Q3W), with the maximum cycle of 17. Suspension of Sintilimab administration: patients's request, disease progression, researcher-evaluated SAE

At least one metastatic lesion is suitable for SBRT. If applicable, all metastatic lesions were allowed to be irradiated. Recommended dose: BED ≥ 80Gy. Dose fractionation is determined as per physician's discretion, generally depending on the location of irradiated lesion and the distance to surrounding OARs. Timing of SBRT: After completing at least 2 platinum-containing chemotherapy plus sintilimab treatments, SBRT can be started after assessing that there is no AE ≥ G2.
Platinum based single or doublet chemotherapy, one cycle every 3 weeks (Q3W), 4-6 cycles.

overall_official.affiliation: Cancer Institute and Hospital, Chinese Academy of Medical Sciences

facility.name: Cancer hospital, Chinese Academy of Medical Sciences
